sub_title: Applications Engineer | Semiconductor Manufacturing | Metrology | Physics PhD
summary: Driving innovation in semiconductor manufacturing through metrology solutions.

projects.title: Ga+ irradiation for zero-field skyrmion stabilization: Towards imaging skyrmions with SEMPA
projects.description:
MSc. project at FNA at TU/e

Skyrmions are magnetic quasi-particles with a chiral spin structure, which is of vital importance for
achieving fast skyrmion velocities in future spintronic devices. In this thesis we take steps towards
investigating their internal structure with scanning electron microscopy with polarization analysis
(SEMPA). To achieve this, a method needs to be found to stabilize skyrmions without magnetic
fields, since SEMPA is impossible in magnetic fields. We propose using an in-situ focused ion
beam (FIB) to achieve zero field skyrmion stabilization in two ways. First, we can make use of the
FIB to disrupt the crystal structure of a sample, changing the fundamental magnetic parameters.
Second, we can use the FIB to remove material outright, which creates confining structures. An
extensive set of micro-magnetic simulations is performed to investigate skyrmion stability and
nucleation in confined geometries, and we show that skyrmions can indeed be stabilized in our
samples at zero-field. Before we are able to use the FIB in experiments, a calibration procedure
is required in the form of domain wall injection experiments. We then investigate changes in the
effective anisotropy and Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (DMI), as a function of the amount of
intermixing caused by Ga+ irradiation, by studying changes in domains and the internal structure
of domain walls with SEMPA. We find indications of a decrease in DMI with Ga+ irradiation
and increased variations of the DMI and effective anisotropy, which is as expected for increased
interface roughness after Ga+ irradiation. The investigations into the domain walls are mostly
inconclusive, but they give the first indications towards understanding how the DMI changes with
Ga+ irradiation. With the results of these experiments, we come closer to imaging skyrmions with
SEMPA, since we are able to predict skyrmion stability in confining geometries and enabled the
use of a FIB to tune magnetic properties.

projects.title: Lorentz TEM investigation of skyrmion grain boundary effects in B20 FeGe
projects.description:
External internship project with the Materials and Condensed Matter Physics group at the University of Glasgow. This project was a part of my masters degree and has been graded 7,5/10.

In this project I investigated phenomena occuring along grain boundaries in skyrmion crystals. Skyrmions are magnetic quasi-particles with a whirling spin structure and are promising candidates for future data-processing devices. The material which was investigated was FeGe with a cubic B20 crystal structure. B20 FeGe is known for hosting skyrmions in a hexagonal array (crystal) near room temperature under applied magnetic fields.

With this project, I formulated a recipe for reliably creating samples hosting numerous skyrmions and I investigated methods for inducing grain boundaries within the skyrmion crystal. Skyrmion dynamics were observed with Lorentz transmission electron microscopy in the Fresnel mode. Indications were found for thermally driven dynamics. Interesting skyrmion deformations were observed in 5-7 defects occuring along the grain boundary. These defects were further investigated with Lorentz scanning TEM in DPC mode. From the DPC images, indications were found that the deformed skyrmions were actually made up of two conjoined skyrmions.

projects.title: Magnetic Force Microscopy on Skyrmionic Systems
projects.description:
Bachelor Thesis at the Physics of Nanostructures (FNA) group at the Eindhoven University of Technology. This project was graded 8/10. 

Magnetic multilayered thin films were investigated with a Magnetic Force Microscope, a magnetic variant of the Atomic Force Microscope. The magnetic force microscope measures gradients in magnetic stray fields to image the magnetic domain structure of a sample. This technique was used to image thin film Ir/Co/Pt multilayers, suspected of containing skyrmions (magnetic spin quasi-particles). 

The images were used to determine domain structures and domain wall growth under applied magnetic fields, estimate the Dzyaloshinskii-Moryia interaction and to determine the presence of skyrmions. These measurements were the first succesful MFM measurements in an applied magnetic field at FNA.

profile_positions.description:
Contribute in enabling customer operations and technical node requirements through:
- Sustaining support: analysis and resolution of customer on-product application issues and or escalations.
- New product introduction: roll-out and implement product deliveries.
- Application projects: Support customer node performance requirements and maximize lithography output in terms of productivity and performance.
profile_positions.title: Applications Engineer - YieldStar Metrology

profile_positions.description:
- Process development and project management within the R&D team.
- Management of experimental setups.
- Contributing to the business development of the start-up.
profile_positions.title: R&D and Device Engineer

profile_positions.description:
- Development of new process applications through my Ph.D. project and contributing to the development of existing processes with other members of the R&D team.
- Responsible for scientific experimental setup(s); managing, development (physical and software), and maintenance.
- Involved in business and overall development of startup; pitching, data security, fundraising, intellectual property.
profile_positions.title: R&D Engineer - PhD Student

profile_positions.description:

- Testing, troubleshooting, and developing customer ERP and BI tools with Microsoft Dynamics AX and Microsoft Excel.
- Website content management and front-end development.
